Award.AwardTitle: Expansion Dynamics and Prethermalization in Ultracold Quantum Gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Progress in science in general, and physics in particular, comes in many flavors. Often experimental observations of an unexpected phenomenon, such as high-temperature superconductivity, trigger the development of new theories. It also happens sometimes that "thought experiments" result in new theories, such as general relativity, that are later tested in actual experiments. In the field of ultracold quantum gases, gases at temperatures that are in the nano-Kelvin regime trapped by means of magnetic fields in ultrahigh vacuum (the ultracold counterpart of plasmas), experimental and theoretical developments often go hand in hand. Experiments with ultracold quantum gases have motivated many recent developments in statistical physics. They have also tested theoretical predictions with an exceptional accuracy. This project involves a close collaboration between the theoretical group of the PI and experimental groups in the US and Europe. The goal is to develop and test increasingly sophisticated theoretical descriptions of nonequilibrium quantum systems while contributing to the development and testing of progressively more accurate and controllable experimental platforms. Under this award, graduate students will be trained in quantum physics and computational physics (e.g., they will write and run codes for supercomputers). The PI will deliver lectures about the experimental and theoretical developments at the local high school to motivate students to pursue careers in STEM.

The PI will study the quantum dynamics of ultracold one-dimensional (1D) gases locally far from equilibrium, as well as their expansion dynamics in 1D. After long expansion times in 1D, the latter dynamics enables the experimental measurement of rapidity distributions, long-thought "theoretical constructs" that were recently measured in a collaboration between the PI and groups at Penn State. A central goal of the new studies will be to test the recently developed theory of generalized hydrodynamics (GHD), and to identify corrections beyond GHD that need to be accounted for theoretically. A second topic to be explored is the dynamics of systems with weakly broken integrability (and, more generally, weakly broken conservation laws) to experimentally test a recently developed theory of prethermalization, and to search for its limits of applicability. A central goal here will be to develop theoretical/experimental tools to predict/measure thermalization rates in a broad range of systems. In addition, the PI's group will develop generalizations of a recently introduced theoretical approach to study equilibrium and far-from-equilibrium dynamics of impenetrable SU(N) fermions, and will study the off-diagonal matrix elements of observables in the eigenstates of integrable interacting Hamiltonians to understand what they can teach us about quantum dynamics and transport close to integrability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the theoretical study of the equilibrium properties and the quantum dynamics of ultracold one-dimensional gases, as well as the study of many-particle integrable and quantum-chaotic systems and the transition between them.

A collaboration between the PI's group and the experimental group of David Weiss at Penn State tested the validity of a hydrodynamic theory (GHD) recently introduced to describe the large-distance long-time dynamics of many-particle integrable systems. In the experiment, bundles of ultracold one-dimensional Bose gases were taken out of equilibrium by means of trap quenches in both the strong and intermediate coupling regimes. The theoretical modeling showed that GHD provides an excellent description of the experimental observations for well over dozens of oscillations, and that GHD is accurate even when particle numbers are low and the density changes are large and fast. Another question explored was that of the processes that take place before GHD becomes applicable. Following quenches with Bragg scattering pulses, the PI's and Weiss' groups identified two time scales that emerge both in the experiments and in the numerical simulations. The shortest one (hydrodynamization, which also occurs in heavy-ion collisions) results in the redistribution of energy across distant momentum modes. Beyond the hydrodynamization time scale it is possible to use generalized hydrodynamics to describe the dynamics of the system. The second time scale results in the redistribution of energy across nearby momentum modes, which leads to local prethermalization.

 

The PI's group developed a theoretical model to describe the rapidity and momentum distributions in experiments of highly magnetic 1D Bose gases of dysprosium in equilibrium carried out by the group of Ben Lev at Stanford. The model, in parallel with the experimental results, showed that in the strongly correlated Tonks-Girardeau regime the rapidity and momentum distributions are nearly unaffected by the dipolar interactions. By contrast, significant changes occur when decreasing the strength of the contact interactions, which increases the average density in the system. The nature of the latter changes in the experiment were correctly described by the model.

 

Using a wide range of theoretical tools, the PI's group and collaborators have made fundamental contributions to the understanding of the effect of conservation laws in the entanglement properties of highly excited eigenstates of many-particle integrable and quantum-chaotic systems. Specifically, closed form expressions were derived for the leading terms in the entanglement entropy for random pure states and random pure Gaussian states, and were numerically shown to describe the behavior of the entanglement entropy of Hamiltonian eigenstates.

 

The PI's group and collaborators explored the onset of quantum chaos upon breaking integrability and Anderson localization and showed that the typical fidelity susceptibility exhibits universal behavior in that regime. The results obtained suggest that, in the thermodynamic limit, arbitrarily small integrability (or localization) breaking perturbations result in quantum chaos in many-body quantum systems. 

 

Four graduate students were partially supported by this award. They all received training in many-body quantum physics and in advanced computational techniques used to study those systems in an unbiased way. They were also trained in writing efficient computational codes (in C or Fortran 90) and in the use of supercomputers. Two of the students completed their PhDs during the three-year period covered by the award.
